Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Maritime Adaptations and Early North Atlantic Fisheries at Gufusk?lar Iceland
Award.AbstractNarration: This award supports a Dissertation Improvement Grant for doctoral student Frank Feeley. Researcher Feeley will be working closely with PI Tom McGovern to explore the site of Gufuskálar in western Iceland. This dissertation improvement grant will support two seasons of archaeological investigation of the site in order to better understand its role in the early "global" economy of Icleand, as well as the origins of the modern world economic system. The site of Gufuskálar is important as it's one of the few surviving examples of the handful of large medieval fishing stations. These stations marked Iceland's introduction into the growing world system of medieval trade, which is the basis for our modern world economic system. The investigation will use a unique methodology of examinining fish crania to determine the movement from subsistence to commodity fisheries in Iceland during the Viking period. In addition, both sea and wind are quickly eroding the site, which is one of the largest medieval fishing stations in Iceland. This project will contribute to the preservation of information in danger of being lost and will contribute to the preservation of this important site itself.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goal with excavating at the 15th century fishing station at Gufuskalar in Western Iceland was to better understand the lives of these early commercial fishermen as well as better understand the methods by which they created the dried fish product that would become a staple food for millions on continental Europe and beyond. The fishing of wild Atlantic Cod is still an important part of Iceland's economy and by better understanding these early fishermen, and their fish, we may help provide fisheries managers data critical for the conservation of this important resource. We had to act quickly, however, as the site was, and continues to be, under threat by coastal erosion. This area of the coast is battered by strong winter storms and since the 1980s we have lost meters of coastline. These storms likely have wiped out about half of the site. It was important that archaeologists excavate as much of the site as possible before it was completely lost.

Gufuskalar was one of the dozen or so big commercial fishing operations in Iceland during the 15th century. Most became the locations for Iceland's first towns and subsequent construction has likely destroyed the remains of these early fishing stations. Gufuskalar is rare in that it was abandoned in the 16th century and thanks to the sandy soil on the coast the site's structures, artifacts, and animal remains are incredibly well preserved. Here we have a chance to better understand the early commercial fishing industry.

For two summers archaeologists from the City University of New York and Fornleifastofnun Íslands (The Icelandic Institute of Archaeology) excavated at the site. Among our excavators were undergraduate and graduate students from CUNY, Arizona State University, Washington State University, University of Oslo, Laval University, and Sterling University. Aside from conserving precious archaeological remains we were also able to help broaden the field experiences of many students. Many in the local fishing communities were also interested in our work. By excavating Gufuskalar we were able to provide a location where people could connect their modern day industry with its origins over five centuries ago. It is hoped that the local tourism officials can fit Gufuskalar in the rich historic narrative of the region and draw more tourists to the west.

In two summers we excavated a complete fishing booth (the site has at least six which haven't been eroded away yet), detailing multiple phases of construction and repair over the course of roughly a century, as well as a four meter deep midden with excellently preserved artifacts and animal bones. Overall we uncovered two tons of faunal remains which are still being analyzed. Preliminary data is suggesting that the fishermen at Gufuskalar may not be the poor desperate people forced by their social betters to fish the dangerous winter waters off of the western coast of Iceland (as is modeled by later fishing enterprises in Iceland) but rather they're being provisioned with expensive cuts of lamb and other luxury meats. Additionally they have access to artifacts, such as ceramic vessels, traded by the continental merchants which are rarely found even at contemporary elite farmsteads. Perhaps these fishermen were entrepreneurs who were taking advantage in changes in the world economy and were able to parlay their skill at fishing to attain wealth.
